episode.title: Frank v. Minnesota Newspaper Association, Inc.

section.heading: Argument of Paul J. Larkin, Jr.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: We'll hear argument first this morning in No. 87-1956, Anthony M. Frank, Postmaster General v. The Minnesota Newspaper Association.
Mr. Larkin?

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.

At issue in this case is the facial constitutionality under the First Amendment of a provision of the Anti-Lottery Act of 1890, an act of Congress that has been on the books for 99 years, and it has already been upheld by this Court over a First Amendment challenge.
The Anti-Lottery Act of 1890 contains two clauses that are relevant here: an advertisement clause and a prize list clause.
The advertisement clause prohibits sending advertisements through the mail.
The prize list clause prohibits sending through the mail lists of prizes drawn or awarded by the lotteries.
Now, this case, however, is now smaller in scope than it was when the Court noted probable jurisdiction in October and when we filed our brief in November.
The district court upheld the constitutionality of the advertisement clause, but that ruling is no longer before the Court.
What is before the Court is the district court's ruling on the constitutionality of the prize list clause.

The district court held that clause unconstitutional on its face on the ground that it was designed to and would prevent a distribution through the mails of news stories that contained lists of prizes awarded by a lottery.
What remains in this case in our view still presents a live controversy between the parties.
That controversy can be decided on the record as it now stands, and that controversy can be resolved in our favor essentially by relying on this Court's precedents.
The judgment below should be reversed for two reasons which I will summarize.
First, the district court misread the scope of the prize list clause.
This Court in the Horner case held that a prize list used in the commercial promotion of a lottery fit within the term "prize list" in the statute.
In our view that is also as far as the statute reaches.
In other words, the prize list clause does not apply to news stories, editorials or similar types of commentary.
It applies only to what today would be called commercial speech.
Second, when the prize list clause is construed in that manner, it is facially constitutional under this Court's decisions in Ex parte Jackson, In re Rapler and Posadas.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, if you exclude news stories and editorials, what kind of a... what have you got left?

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: What you have left, Your Honor, is the type of prize list that this Court addressed in the Horner case, and that shows up in some of the examples we've reprinted in the appendix to our brief.
In the appendix to our opening brief, we've reprinted several examples of what were prize lists that were distributed during the period before this Act became law.
If you look to page 11a to 12a, you'll see an advertisement that was distributed in behalf of the Louisiana Lottery, which was the most famous or infamous lottery in the 19th century.
If you look to the top of page 12a, you will see a section entitled "List of Prizes".
At page 14a in the appendix is another prize list, this one distributed on behalf of the Kentucky lottery.
Now, those examples we think are important because that is what this Court construed the Act to cover in the Horner case.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: This was... these were just separate lists mailed... sent through the mails to addressees.

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: Correct.
They could be put... put out by lotteries by purchasing advertising space or space for the promotion of a prize list in a newspaper.
And then the newspaper was sent out across the country.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, but... but I thought the ads were already out of the case.

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: The... the... the constitutionality of the advertisement clause is out of the case.
You're correct.
But what is in--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But if you buy space in the newspaper to publish your prize list, isn't that an ad?

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: --Not necessarily, no, because Congress adopted two different clauses in the statute because I think it saw that there were two different types of promotional materials being used.
The types of promotional materials you see here that would constitute a prize list is the same type of promotional material the Court addressed in the Horner case.
We have reprinted in our brief at page 30, footnote 27, what this Court addressed in the Horner case.
The prize list that is reprinted at that part of our brief is the same as the ones here.
What was happening in the 19th century was that you had two different types basically of promotional materials being used.
You had an advertisement that didn't include the lists of what could be awarded.
That, for example, is at page 13a of our appendix.
And then you had other types of promotional materials that basically just consisted of a list of what the lottery would award.
Congress drafted the statute to include both types of materials.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But, Mr. Larkin, I'm still a little puzzled.
Those lists were not sent out in newspapers, were they?

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: They could be, yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, yes, but... but now they have to pay to do it.

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: Yes.
And if they pay to do it--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Then it's an ad.

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: --No, it would not necessarily be an add.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Well, have you got an example anywhere in the world of such a list being published by a newspaper without... when it was paid for and it was not an ad?

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: Well, the one we've reprinted at pages 11a to 12a, the one from the Louisiana Lottery, was called an ad by the Postal Service at the time, but it contained a list of prizes.
You could--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: But it wasn't in a newspaper.

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: --Yes, it was.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Oh, I'm sorry.
I misunderstood.

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: See, both of these types of promotional materials... the one we have, for example, at page 13a, which is just basically a little flyer about the Louisiana Lottery would be seen as an advertisement in the period, like letting people know the lottery existed.
And then you had other types of promotional materials that told them the prizes you could actually win if you entered.
And Congress drafted the statute to include both.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But just how were the prize lists... they were... were they a flyer in the newspaper or reprinted on some page of the newspaper?

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: They... they could occur in both ways.
For example, at the time some lotteries in the 19th century actually tried to take advantage of the loophole in the 1876 Act by publishing their own lottery newspapers.
For example, the postal... the Postmaster General pointed that out to Congress when they were considering this statute.

So, in that case what you could have is the, say, Kentucky Lottery newspaper that was being printed, and you could have reprinted as the same way you have advertisements at grocery stores nowadays an advertisement about the lottery or list of the prizes that the lottery was going to award.

You also could have the situation in which even if it wasn't a newspaper that was sponsored by the lottery itself, the... the lottery could purchase space in the newspaper to reprint the advertisement or the prize list.
Let me explain some of the background to this, and it may help answer your question.
In the 19th century, gambling, particularly lotteries, were treated with the same contempt that narcotics trafficking is today.
That's clear not only from the materials that were before Congress, the statements by Presidents of the United States, but from the decisions of this Court.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: And yet, the... your illustration of the Louisiana State Lottery under the personal supervision and management of General G. I. Beauregard and General Jubal A. Early of Virginia, rather prominent figures in the 19th century.

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: Absolutely.

And, in fact, it was that reason that they were used by the Louisiana Lottery because they were... they were asked by the Louisiana Lottery to... to lend their name to this enterprise in order to add an air of respectability to it.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: And they lent their names.

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: Correct.
But, nonetheless, it was the Louisiana Lottery that ultimately was the target of this statute.
By 1890, after a nationwide effort extending over several decades, most states... in fact, every state except Louisiana... had prohibited this type of activity.
Louisiana allowed the Louisiana Lottery to engage in business, however, and it engaged in business on a nationwide scale and made an enormous amount of money as a result.

It engaged in business on a nationwide scale by putting advertisements and other types of promotional materials in newspapers, and the reason it put those materials in newspapers is that the existing 1876 law that this Court upheld in the Jackson case did not apply to newspapers.

The result was there was no existing way at that time for any of the other states in the Nation or Congress... excuse me... or the executive to do anything about the existence of the Louisiana Lottery.
However, Congress decided it was time to shut it down.

It decided that the only way effectively to do so was to deny the Louisiana Lottery access to its primary source of income which was money from out-of-state bettors since the Louisiana Lottery received more than 90 percent of its income from out-of-state bettors.
The result of that was the Anti-Lottery Act of 1890.
Congress passed that law in order to deny the Louisiana Lottery the opportunity to use newspapers for... for promoting their own financial success.
It was that type of prize list or that type of advertisement that Congress was concerned about.
Congress was not intending to prevent a newspaper from writing a news story about a lottery, about a lottery winner or about a lottery prize list.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: How do we know that?

I mean, you know, it... very often Congress is concerned about one particular aspect of a problem, and it drafts a statute that covers that, but to be prophylactic covers a few things beyond that as well.

I have no confidence at all that if you asked one of those original legislators, well, what if... what if a newspaper just wrote a news story, not an advertisement, just a news story, said, look it, these are the great money prizes that you can get in the Louisiana Lottery, I think it's quite plausible that that Senator would have said, yes, I think... don't like that any better.

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: I have several--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I mean, it seems to me that you are... you are dealing in an anachronism here.
You're... you're casting back upon the 1890 Congress our modern notion of commercial speech.
They didn't know about the distinction between commercial speech and other speech.
We've invented that in recent years.
And why should I ever think that they had it in mind in 1890?

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: --I don't suggest that the Congress that passed this statute was thinking in terms of the... you know, the four-part Central Hudson test or any of the other cases that this Court has decided.
But what I do say is this.
Congress passed this statute to prevent lotteries from being commercially promoted.
That purpose dovetails nicely we think with the commercial speech doctrine the Court has today, and we think that is what they were concerned about.
You didn't have news stories about lotteries then because--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Concerned about their being promoted commercially or otherwise.
Why... why should I think they were just concerned about their being commercially promoted?
To be sure, that was the main way they were promoted, but I have no basis for thinking that they wouldn't have been concerned about their being promoted in any fashion, commercially or otherwise.

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: --Well, it's possible that if you had a different set of facts before Congress, they would have been concerned about that.
But you didn't have news stories about lotteries because there was only one state, Louisiana, where they were lawful.
And newspapers themselves supported this Act.

Congress certainly believed that the majority of newspapers supported the legislation that it was putting forward, and I doubt the newspapers themselves would have supported this Act if they thought it was going to censure their ability to report about stories.

Congress dealt with a particular problem, and it's the goal that Congress had in mind, the purpose of that statute, that should influence the construction here, and that is so even apart from the concerns expressed in cases like Catholic Bishop about construing statutes in order for them to be constitutional.

We don't think Congress, which debated the constitutionality of this type of statute under the law that the Court had set forth in the Jackson case, intended this type of statute here to reach more broadly.
Congress certainly hasn't shown any indication of intending in more recent times that the statute be read that broadly.
The statute was revisited in 1974.
The statute was revisited last year, and there's no reason to believe that Congress is not aware of what the historic construction is.

In fact, Justice Scalla, there is no hint in this Court's opinion in the Rapler case, which was decided two years after the statute was passed, or in the Horner case, which was decided three years after the statute was passed, that this Act applied to news stories.
And the people on this Court at that time were certainly aware of what the statute was designed to deal with.
As I said, lotteries in the 19th century were as well-known and as despised as narcotics trafficking is today.
The fact that this Court twice at that early stage didn't hesitate to even ask the question whether it applied to news stories I think is significant evidence that the statute doesn't reach that--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Mr. Larkin, suppose I disagree with you.
Suppose I think it means what it says and... and why... why couldn't I say that it's valid as applied to all... all commercial speech and not valid as applied to other speech?
Why couldn't I handle the problem that way?

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: --Well, if the statute is limited so that it applies only to commercial speech--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: No, I'm saying it's written to apply to everything, but it's... it's unconstitutional insofar as it extends beyond commercial speech.
Why can't I say that?

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: --Well, the statute still cannot be held facially unconstitutional, which is the ruling below, the one we are challenging, unless it is substantially overbroad, and we don't think it meets that test.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Or why couldn't we adopt a new rule that in addition to being substantially overbroad... if it's overbroad in a fashion that can be limited very clearly, as most... most overbroad statutes can, where the only overbreadth consists of extending beyond commercial speech.
It's a very clear line that you can make by judicial decision.
Why couldn't I hold that a facial challenge can be rejected if the only overbreadth consists of going beyond commercial?

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: We think you can, and we ask in this case for the district court's judgment which dealt only with the facial constitutionality of the statute to be reversed.
If there are problems of the type that are concerning you, those problems can be worked out when the statute is applied in particular cases.
That's what an as-applied type of challenge is for.
But the district court held the statute facially invalid.
We have argued that the statute should be construed to be limited to lotteries... excuse me... to prize lists used commercially to promote lotteries.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Tell... tell us again what the prize list clause covers that the advertising clause doesn't cover.

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: The prize list clause covers circumstances in which you offer a prize in... for entry in the lottery, and the advertising clause covers other types of commercial promotion.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, now... now, wait a minute.
Why does... why is the first example you mention that you say is covered by the prize list clause but not by the advertising clause... why isn't that covered by the advertising clause?

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: It... there is some overlap between the two.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, exactly.
What I'm trying to find out is what the prize list clause reaches that the advertising clause doesn't reach.

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: The prize list clause would reach the case where you just basically have the list of prizes that the lottery is being... that the lottery is offering, perhaps with the title of the lottery, like the--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Where?
Where do you have it?
How did it come into existence... this thing you're talking about?

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: --Well, prize lists were... were used in circulars and other types of promotional materials.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So, it would be mailings of prize lists that don't appear in the newspapers, for example, but there could be prize lists, I take it, that would be in the newspaper that you think the prize list clause would cover.

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: Yes, I agree with Your Honor.
The prize list clause could apply to newspapers and to other types of circulars.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But why wouldn't the advertising clause cover a prize list that appears in a newspaper and is paid for by some sponsor?

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: Because we don't think Congress intended the prize... excuse me... the advertisement clause just to be limited... to reach in that manner.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Why not?

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: In adopting a... well, by adopting a separate prize list clause, it seems that Congress thought it was dealing with two somewhat overlapping but, nonetheless, somewhat distinct types of promotional materials.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I would think... that's pretty fine.
That's a pretty fine... I can understand that the prize list clause would surely cover mailings of prize lists and circulars to a bunch of addressees.
There's no doubt... not much question about that, but I suppose the prize list clause, since it has been declared invalid on its face, couldn't even reach those circulars.

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: That's right.
The district court's judgment wouldn't allow the prize list clause to be applied in any manner to circulars, to newspaper stories, to even illegal uses of a lottery, such as a numbers racket.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Now, if the... if there's a news story on the front page of the paper saying here is... here are the prizes that this new lottery will offer.
It tells about the lottery starting up and who is sponsoring it.
It's a news story.
Then they have a... they have the very list that you find in the back of the paper that has been paid for in this news story.
You say that... that is not covered by the prize list.

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: No, a bona fide news story is not.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: We don't think that the statute should be read to prevent the press from reporting about factual events and--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: --Well, not... not events.
This is... they're reporting what you can win in the lottery.

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: --That's right.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Here's the list.

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: It's an event to occur in the future and we don't think that the prize list clause properly construed should apply to simple, straightforward news stories in the manner--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Or a news story that says... a news story that sums up and makes a great list of the prizes that have been won in the last year in the lottery.

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: --Correct.
If the lottery purchases the space in the newspaper to list all the prizes they have awarded in the past 10 years, to list all the prizes that they are going to award--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That's covered.

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: --That would be covered.
If the newspaper sells the advertising space, that would be covered.

But if the newspaper on its own prints a story either because it thinks its newsworthy or because it wants to just let the public play in the lottery by telling them about it, that wouldn't be covered.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But the example you just gave is not an ad.

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: Correct.
If it's just a list of prizes and, say, the name of the lottery, I don't think Congress thought that that was an advertisement.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: And if it says this is an advertisement paid for by the XYZ Lottery Company, it's still not an ad.
Why do... why do you care whether it is or not?

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: Well, we're trying to be faithful to this fact that there are two separate clauses in the statute, and--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, you've already got some... some coverage for the prize... for the prize clause: circulars.

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: --That's right, but we think if you use the same material that goes in the circular in a newspaper, it would be covered there too.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Mr. Larkin, I'm not sure you have circulars.
I... I don't... I don't agree with your... your answer to Justice White on that.
The first clause of 1302 covers any letter, package, postal card or circular concerning any lottery.
That first clause would cover a list of prizes put into an envelope with a stamp on it and sent.
That would be a circular concerning any lottery whether it's an advertisement or a list of prizes or anything else.

The clause we're talking about here only, I believe, deals with material that is not inserted into an envelope, but that goes as a general publication to the general public, newspaper, circular, pamphlet or publication of any kind.
I think they mean to distinguish between a publication and the kind of circulars that are... that are mailed to... to individuals.

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I don't see the meaning of the first clause if... if you're reading this one the way you do to cover something put into an envelope to a private individual.

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: --Well, let... let me explain then if... the difference here between the two.
The circular part of the statute to which you were referring was part of the original 1876 law.
The part of the statute that includes the prize list phrase was the part that was added by the 1890 law that was designed to deal with newspapers.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: xxx.

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: That's right.
So, when I was answering Justice White's question, what I was trying to say was you could have prize lists that show up in circulars because that's what happened in the Horner case.
But the part of the statute that you have at issue under the district court's judgment is the part of the statute that's designed to deal with newspapers.
So, as a factual historical matter, you could have a prize list show up in a circular.
And the circular clause that you mentioned would cover it.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: xxx.

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: But when the prize list shows up in the newspaper, then it is covered by the clause that we're dealing with here because that was part of the 1890--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: But doesn't that leave Justice White's question still on the table then?
What does it cover besides... besides advertisements?
Isn't that kind of a prize list an advertisement?

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: --I don't think so if it's just simply the list of the prizes they are going to award, Congress must have thought that that was specifically addressed by the prize list clause rather than the advertisement clause.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, I... it seems to me that... I don't know why you care whether it's an ad or not.
The ad... the ad provision has been sustained, and if all... if all non-editorial prize lists in a paper are ads, there's no problem.
But I take it you concede that if the prize list is read to cover editorial prize lists, it's unconstitutional.
Is that it?

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: If the prize list clause is read to apply to a general news story?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Uh-hum.

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: We would... we would say that it would be unconstitutional in that respect.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, all right.
And so, what's the big problem in the case?
If it covers... if it covers editorials... editorial prize lists, it's bad.

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: Well, if--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And If it covers paid-for prize lists, and... and if the ads... the ad provision covers paid-for prize lists, it's all right.

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: --But if the newspaper is operating the lottery as... or is owned by the lottery, as happened in the 19th century, then you don't have a bona fide news story, and if they just list the prizes, then it would be within the prize list clause.

As I tried to explain earlier, there were instances in the 19th century in which a lottery published what they called a lottery newspaper, and in that circumstance, just listing the prizes would not be a bona fide news story because it would be used commercially to promote the lottery.

In fact, if you didn't include within the type of commercial speech that we're talking about here situations in which a lottery newspaper is covered, then you're creating an exemption that allows the lottery just to print something that they call a lottery newspaper and advertise their prize lists freely in that manner.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: So, but the newspapers here don't plan to do that.
There's no indication that they are going to do that, is there?

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: No, I don't... do not believe so.
But the statute was held facially invalid, and for that reason we think the district court was wrong.

If the newspapers in this case became shareholders in a lottery, then you have a different story, and the question of the constitutionality or construction of the statute should be construed in that context.
But here the district court held it facially invalid, and we don't think it's facially invalid.
We think it can properly be applied.

When it's read in the manner that we have suggested or when it's limited to the types of material that we have said the statute should be limited to, we think the statute is a lawful regulation of commercial speech under the Jackson, Rapler and Posadas cases.
Rapler, for example, upheld this very statute, and Posadas upheld a very similar ban on casino gambling.
As a matter of precedent, therefore, we think this statute passes muster, and we also think that precedent makes good policy sense.
What you have here is a situation in which Congress has attempted to deal with a narrow category of materials such as firearms, alcohol, cigarettes, narcotics or legalized prostitution.
These are areas that government has historically regulated under the morals head of its police power.
One of the ways of regulating it is to limit advertising.
This Court upheld the constitutionality of that judgment by Congress a century ago.
We ask the Court to do so again today.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Counsel, if the newspapers were willing to forego all claims for equitable relief and to have this judgment vacated in... in its entirety, would the case then be moot?

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: If the Court allowed them to dismiss their complaint, then there would be no... there would no longer be a case.
But they... they don't have a right to dismiss their complaint because we filed our answer.
And we would urge the Court not to grant the motion because this part of the statute was not changed by the most recent amendments.

The constitutional question presented here, therefore, is one that is of practical importance to the Postal Service, and that the Postal Service would ask this Court to decide based on the record in our favor.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Larkin.
Mr. DeVore?

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court.

The government has served up in its briefs and in oral argument today a number of historical examples of historical prize lists which may or may not be real today, but certainly are not things which are before the Court in this case.
We submit that this case if over, that each side agrees that the other is entitled to the outcome that it seeks, and we ask the Court to close the case on the statutory construction point.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: But you're not willing to have the entire judgment vacated.

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: We are willing to have the entire judgment vacated, Justice Kennedy, but I think the Court in doing so should explain the logic used by the Court in reaching that point.
And I think you must face the statutory construction point.

The government and we basically agree that it is proper to construe the statute not to apply to fully protected speech, but I think in order to... to... to reach that point, you've got to go through some of the logic in the... in, for example, Catholic Bishop and DeBartolo from last term to understand where you... how you get there.
It's not the sort of mootness situation that you find in a... oh, say, the DeFunis case or others where an intervening event has disposed of the case.
Congress acted here and passed the Charitable Games Act and the Indian Gaming Statute after the Court noted jurisdiction on both appeals here.
We dismissed our appeal on the advertising clause based on that intervening event.
The prize list clause is all that's still before the Court.
So, we agree with the government that the... the court went too far below.
We didn't ask for a holding of facial unconstitutionality.
The district court provided that because it was apparently concerned about the reach that the government argued for into news and editorial fully protected speech.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, don't you... why don't you defend that?

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: Well, I have... would have no doubt, Justice White, that if--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: The government concedes that--

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: --this applied--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: --The government concedes that if you construe it to cover that, it's unconstitutional.

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: --They did construe that... they did concede that here today to the Court in oral argument.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Why do you want that vacated?

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: Well, I would be pleased to have a... an eloquent holding of the Court that an... another holding of the Court, because there are many that the Court has done in the past, that a statute which would purport to apply to news and editorial copy would meet... would not meet the strict scrutiny test which I think was held by the district court.
The district court just went a little too far in... in holding that it was facially unconstitutional and enjoining all applications, including applications not before the court.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: xxx left of the prize clause that if you eliminate news stories and editorials?

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: I'm not sure I know the answer to that.

The government has given some examples, possibly... and the example in the Horner case of circulars sent by a lottery sponsor to people who were already in the game may well be something that might be covered by it.
But that--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What about a--

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: --is certainly not an advertisement in a newspaper.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: --What about... what about a so-called lottery newspaper, a lottery publishes a newspaper or a newspaper runs a lottery, whichever one you want to say?

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: Well, the issue there would be one which would still be open to the Court if you accept the... either holding, either that this is... the statute is unconstitutional as applied to the only speech at issue in this case, news and editorial copy, or you simply say that as construed under Catholic Bishop and DeBartolo, you needn't reach those things.
It would still be open to the Postal Service to attempt to apply it in a situation.

Then the Court would be confronted or a court would be confronted with the question of whether you had commercial speech at all under the tests of... you know, adduced by the court, and then if you had commercial speech, whether in fact the regulation of that speech was permissible under Central Hudson.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What if we were to conclude for one reason or another, Mr. DeVore, that the statute should be construed to cover only the sort of commercial speech that you've adverted to and Mr. Larkin has adverted to?
what... what does... what does that do to the judgment here?
The judgment of the district court is... is too broad.

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: It's too broad.
Really, the only thing before the Court is news and editorial copy.

The only point I'd make, Justice Rehnquist, on the construction point is that I think that where the government gets off track in application of the construction cases, Catholic Bishop and DeBartolo, is that Instead of stopping at the stopping point that that prudential rule is designed to achieve for the Court, namely, avoiding the decision of constitutional issues if you don't find a clear intent of Congress to cover the thing that's before the Court in the case... what the government does is to say... it goes a step further and says what the statute still covers is commercial speech.
The Court simply need not decide under Catholic bishop or DeBartolo what's left under the statutory section.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: So, you say that all you're asking for is the sort of relief that will exclude newspaper stories about lotteries, which the government concedes the statute doesn't cover.

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: That is all the relief we've ever sought in regard to the prize list clause--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: And therefore, the... the district court went too far--

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: --That's right.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --but that we should not go beyond what you've asked for and construe the statute other than it's saying it does not apply to what you're trying to do.

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: I believe that's correct.
The Court does not need to do that.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Did you try this case below, Mr. DeVore?

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: Pardon me, sir?

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Did you try this case before Judge Magnuson?

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: No, I did not.
I was not present when the case was tried with Judge Magnuson, but I have reviewed the... all the documents that were filed with the court.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Was there an attempt to keep him within bounds along the lines that have been discussed this morning?

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: There really was not that kind of discussion.

The government's brief... memorandum argued in the alternative to the court that... that if the statute were to be applied to news and editorial copy, that it would meet the strict scrutiny tests of fully protected speech.
But if it did not and if the court held it only to apply to commercial speech, then it applied the commercial speech analysis.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: So, you feel the government would change its position from the position it took below before Judge Magnuson.

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: From reading... from reading the... the government's memorandum in the case, I would say that the government has not changed its position.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, didn't the newspaper, though, take the position that the... that the prize clause was unconstitutional on its face?
Didn't they ask for a judgment like that?

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: No, they did not, Mr. Justice White.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: They did not.

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: They asked solely for a judgment that it was unconstitutional as applied to news and editorial copy.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So, you don't think there was any case or controversy before the court on non-editorial prize lists.

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: I think once you've gone through the construction analysis, no controversy remains in this case.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, I thought the newspapers had also asked to invalidate the... the requirement concerning ads.

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: Yes, indeed, they did, Justice O'Connor.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: I mean, more was asked below--

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: Exactly.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --than we have before us now.
So--

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: And quite frankly, below the advertising clause was the one that loomed most important in the minds of the newspaper because they were under that clause--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: --Well, yes, that's their revenue.

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: --That's right.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: That was what they were in there to litigate.
Isn't that right?

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: They were prevented from... from running... by the Postal Service applying that from running advertisements of locally legal lotteries in Minnesota--

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: But that issue is now out of the case.

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: --Yes, it's gone.
It's gone.
Congress fixed that or at least they fixed it to the satisfaction of the papers.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well... well--
--Well, that's right.
It's--
--But I... but why should that part of the Judgment... if you don't want to defend that or attack that judgment, why shouldn't that part of the judgment... why should that be vacated?

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: I'm not suggesting that the advertising judgment should be vacated.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Okay.
So, the... that... the the advertising clause... the judgment upholding that stands.

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: That stands.
I mean, it was prize lists and nothing but prize lists, Justice White.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Okay.

Well, but in... in fact, you... you don't... the only reason it's out of the case is not because you agree with the government on it, but because you are affected by that decision for one year until the new statute comes into effect.

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: Actually 18 months, Justice Scalia.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Eighteen months.

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And you just... you just say, well, we don't care anymore.
It isn't--

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: Well--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --It's not that you're in legal agreement at all.

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: --No, that's correct.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: And it's... and it's not that you're not affected by it.
You are affected by it.
You just don't... you just now no longer want to litigate over... over that effect.
Right?

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: We will be affected by it... the newspapers in Minnesota and elsewhere... until May of 1990.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But the judgment stands.

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: The judgment stands.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, when you say the judgment stands, let me--

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: The dismissal.
The dismissal stands and that is no longer at issue in the case.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --You have dismissed your appeal.

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: That's correct.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Okay.
So, it's stands simply because there was an adverse judgment entered in the district court to you and you have not appealed from it.

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: That is the... that's the net result of where we are.

I would like... not that the Court needs reminding in great detail about Catholic Bishop and DeBartolo, but I think it's important to address a question that Justice Scalia put to the government about the legislative history of this... of this statute.

And incidentally, on February 21, I contacted the Deputy Solicitor General, after we had gotten deeply into the briefing process, and suggested a joint motion to this Court based on what was then the agreed construction of this statute to ask the Court to dismiss this case, vacate the judgment below.
So, we... we felt, at least a month ago, that... that this was the result that was certainly acceptable to us.
The statutory construction analysis of the... of NLRB v. Catholic Bishop really fits this case like a glove.
In that case, the Court will recall the National Labor Relations Board had applied the jurisdiction under the NLRA to some mixed religious and secular schools in the... in the Archdiocese of Chicago.
That was appealed by the... by the Archbishop, and it went to the Seventh Circuit which held that application facially unconstitutional.
That was, in turn, appealed by the board to this Court.

And this Court determined that under the... going back to Mr. Justice Marshall's opinion in Murray v. The Charming Betsy in 1804, the prudential notion that this Court shouldn't decide constitutional questions and get into the actions of Congress on... to judge them constitutionally unless there really were a reason to do so.
If that could be avoided by construction, the Court should do it.
In Catholic Bishop, the Court announced a version of that rule which I think is a little more precise and objective than earlier versions.
What it said was that a two-step test should be applied.

Number one... this was a narrow question... if the application of the statute... too in this case it was the religious activity, another clause of the First Amendment... was such as to raise this kind of sensitive constitutional issue, then you went to the words.
You went to Congress and you went to the act.

You went to the legislative history and you found out if, in fact, it was a clearly expressed intention of Congress to apply the broad language of the... in this case the jurisdiction clause of the act... to this kind of sensitive activity.
And if you didn't find that, absent that, then it was to be construed not to apply.
Now, the same... the Court was divided in Catholic Bishop.

The Court really joined last year in DeBartolo v. Florida Building Trades and applied what it called the traditional rule of Catholic Bishop in a similar situation dealing directly with speech in a peaceful hand-billing situation in a Florida shopping mall.

I think it's terribly important that what those cases hold applies here in that a careful reading, Justice Scalia, of the... not just the... the Anti-Lottery Act of 1890, but the many pages of text of the House report, and all of the reports in the history, you simply find no expression on the part of the sponsors of the bill to apply this to news and editorial.
It seemed fairly clear that at least as far as newspapers were concerned... and newspapers were added to the Act, as the Government has said, for the first time in 1890.
What they were concerned about was the advertising.
They mentioned the prize lists, but it appeared to be their assumption that that was something which, as far as newspapers went, was included within advertising.
There was no expression of any intent to cover news and editorial.
And [inaudible] cases--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: I assume that Marbury v. Madison would have come out differently on that kind of a theory.

The difficult constitutional question of whether a mandamus could have applied to a... to a cabinet officer being so difficult and Congress not having explicitly said in the statute at issue whether mandamus would apply to a high level cabinet officer, we wouldn't have reached the issue, would we?
We... we would have just said this statute does not apply to cabinet officers.

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: --I believe that's correct, Justice--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Boy, it's going to change a lot of our law, isn't it?
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: --Well, in any event, it is... it is... we agree with the government.

The government, as I said earlier, went a... went a little different direction after citing DeBartolo and Catholic Bishop at page 28 of their brief to this Court, and went on not just to stop with what the Act does not cover, avoiding the constitutional problem here, but went on to say what the Act does cover.

And I think a great deal of attention has been given by the government to deciding what is commercial speech, what would it apply to other kinds of lotteries that newspapers might or might not be involved in or other parties, professional gamblers might or might not be involved in.

But because the only issue before this Court is the application to the fully protected news and editorial speech about lotteries, we submit that your... your prudential construction rules get us to a common stopping place.
And we ask that the Court vacate the judgment below based on that analysis and lift the injunction in the case.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And not try to define or redefine commercial speech?

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: We don't think that those sensitive issues are before the Court today.

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: Vacate the entire judgment?

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: Yes, Justice Kennedy.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, not the advertising.

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: I'm sorry.
That... vacate the entire judgment as to the prize list clause.
The advertising judgment of the court will stand.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Do we vacate or do we... do we remand with instructions as... as we did in the case... what was it... Deakins, the case you cite to support--

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: Deakins v. Monaghan.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: --We... we directed the... the court to dismiss with prejudice.
Is that... is that what--

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: I puzzled over the--

turn.speaker: anthony_m_kennedy
turn.label: Justice Anthony M. Kennedy
turn.text: --you're willing to have entered here?

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: --I puzzled over the kind of metaphysical differences between reversal and vacation and dismissal with prejudice.
I think that--

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: Dismissal with prejudice sounds worse to me, don't you think?

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: --It sounds... it sounds awful.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: It sounds a little worse.
[Laughter]
But that's what we did in--

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: We would have no... no objection assuming the Court analyzes this from a construction point of view and does not apply it to the speech we brought to the Court, as a matter of concern under the prize list clause, then the vacation of the facial holding below with prejudice is of no concern to us.

But we would ask, given the government's change of position, given the... the concession in the government's brief at page 9 of their reply brief, that, in fact, there is confusion in the Postal Service, we would ask that the Court articulate the reason for this so there is some guidance, as counsel for the government has asked, for those Postal Service employees that this does not reach into news and editorial copy.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: --Well, I don't think we're quite as limited as you suggest in the extent to which we can review the judgment of the district court.
The district court held the statute unconstitutional on its face.
The government has appealed from that ruling.

And the fact that you don't see... that the sort of construction which the government wants to put on it to save it from being held unconstitutional on its face would not hurt you doesn't at this stage of the litigation mean that we couldn't write an opinion, it seems to me, upholding the government's position and still not hurt you in any way.
That would mean that the judgment of the district court would be reversed.

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: Yes, if I understand, Justice Rehnquist.

You could certainly write... if the government's position is that it's not to be construed to be applied to this kind of speech, I would have certainly no... we would have certainly no objection to that kind of decision of the Court.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, and of course we write lots of opinions to which counsel do have objection.
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: Yes, right.
But I just want to make clear whatever... however the Court writes it... and I think there are, as Justice Scalia suggests, there are several ways around the barn to accomplish that result.

And I don't know what the exact word is to describe what the Court does, but we certainly feel that as far as this case is concerned... and it's the application of this clause, the news and editorial copy, the case is over because we do accept that construction as... as required by your authorities.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: Well, it sounds like you'd be satisfied if we vacated, reversed or affirmed.
Isn't that right?

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: Well, we... we have certainly not asked that it be affirmed, and I suspect it would not be proper for the Court to do that.

turn.speaker: sandra_day_oconnor
turn.label: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor
turn.text: That would reach the result you would be happy with.

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: But that would, in fact... somewhat probably ironically, it would have the same result in regard to the speech at issue in the case today.

turn.speaker: antonin_scalia
turn.label: Justice Antonin Scalia
turn.text: You're clear that you want this case off our docket, though.
Right?
[Laughter]

turn.speaker: p_cameron_devore
turn.label: Mr. P. Cameron DeVore
turn.text: I think my feeling is sufficient unto the day to resolve the other sensitive issues raised by the government in the case.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. DeVore.
Mr. Larkin, you have four minutes remaining.

section.heading: Rebuttal of Paul J. Larkin, Jr.

turn.speaker: paul_j_larkin_jr
turn.label: Mr. Paul J. Larkin, Jr.
turn.text: Just a few points, Your Honor.
I think it was Justice O'Connor asked about the scope of the relief they asked for.
The scope of the relief they asked for in district court was not limited to advertisements and news stories.

Page 8 of the joint appendix reprints their request, and they ask the statute to be held void to the extent they prohibit or interfere with the publication of information about lawful gaming activities regardless of the form.
So, they asked for the statute to be held invalid insofar as it prevented them from publishing any information about lawful gaming activities, not just advertisements and not just news stories.
Secondly, I don't think it is we that have changed our position in this case.
After all, the Appellee filed a motion to affirm in which it asked this Court summarily to affirm the judgment below.
Appellee has now said that it doesn't mind if the case is affirmed, reversed, vacated or disposed of in some other manner.
But our construction of the statute has been consistent throughout.
We asked the district court not to read the statute to apply to news stories.
We ask the Court not to read the statute that way today.
We ask the Court to uphold the statute in the manner we have suggested.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Thank you, Mr. Larkin.
The case is submitted.
